title: U.S. stocks rise 15% on average one year after midterms, analysts find
text:
As candidates across the country duke it out with their challengers, investors can rest assured that their portfolios will likely see strong returns â€” that is, if the past is any guide, according to research from Strategas.

With the midterms just 62 days away, a team of equity strategists from Strategas found that since 1946, U.S. stocks have never traded lower 12 months after a midterm vote.

Instead, the index has typically seen robust gains, rising 15% on average excluding dividends. By comparison, the S&P 500 SPX has seen an average price increase of 7.1% a year on average since the index was created in 1957, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

Using a more current time frame, the average annualized price gain from Sept. 6, 2012 through Tuesday's close is 10.6%, according to Dow Jones Market Data. Both of these figures exclude dividends.

MarketWatch reported back in 2018 that while the S&P 500 typically underperforms in the 12 months leading up to the midterms, that dynamic shifts to outperformance in the 12 months that follow.

To be sure, historical trends don't guarantee future outperformance. And there are still risks surrounding the midterms, including the likelihood that President Joe Biden could face a more divided Congress. While Democrats now enjoy a majority in the House, their majority in the Senate is razor-thin, and complicated by high inflation and two conservative Democrats who occasionally resist the president's agenda.

According to 538's election tracker, polling shows Republicans are generally favored to win the House in November, while Democrats are slightly favored to retain control of the Senate.

Polling by J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. has shown that Wall Street professionals generally expect Republicans to seize control of both the House and the Senate.

This means President Biden could face a more divided government, which could create problems for the market, as MarketWatch has previously reported.

So far this year, the S&P 500 SPX has fallen 17.5%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA is off by 13.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite COMP is down 25.8%. Stocks traded higher on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq set to snap its longest losing streak since 2016, which was a historic year for American politics.

U.S. stocks rise 15% on average one year after midterms, analysts find
